ğŸ¯ Why This Chapter Matters

Before solving problems, you must understand why you are solving them.

LeetCode is not just a website.

ğŸ¤” What is LeetCode?

LeetCode is an online platform for practicing:

  • Algorithms
  • Data Structures
  • Logical problem solving
  • Interview-style coding questions

Problems range from:

  • Beginner (arrays, loops)

ğŸŒ Who Uses LeetCode?

  • Google
  • Meta (Facebook)

  • Microsoft
  • Apple
  • Netflix
  • Startups & research labs

Even if the interview is not on LeetCode,

ğŸ§  What LeetCode Is REALLY Training

  • Recognize patterns
  • Choose the right data structure
  • Optimize time & memory
  • Explain your reasoning clearly

ğŸ” What Interviewers Look For

  • Clear understanding of the problem
  • Logical step-by-step reasoning
  • Clean, readable code
  • Correct time complexity (Big-O)
  • Ability to improve a slow solution

ğŸ§ª Interview Reality Check

You are usually expected to:

  1. Explain the problem in your own words
  2. Start with a simple (even slow) solution
  3. Analyze time complexity
  4. Improve it
  5. Communicate clearly

Perfect code â‰  Perfect interview

ğŸ§  Common Beginner Misunderstanding

Does LeetCode measure intelligence?

âŒ No

item.title: CS101-LC02 â€” Big-O Intuition
item.description:
ğŸ¯ Why Big-O Matters

Big-O is NOT about:

  • Exact seconds
  • CPU speed
  • Programming language

Big-O is about scaling.

â“ If input becomes 10Ã— bigger, how much slower will your program be?

Thatâ€™s what interviewers, professors, and engineers care about.

ğŸ§  Simple Definition

Big-O describes how an algorithmâ€™s runtime or memory grows as input size increases.

We focus on:

  • Worst-case behavior
  • Growth trend
  • Ignoring constants

ğŸ• Real-World Analogy

Imagine finding your name in a list of students.

Case 1: You know your seat number

â†’ You check once
âœ… Constant time â†’ O(1)

Case 2: Names listed randomly

â†’ You scan one by one
ğŸ“ˆ Linear â†’ O(n)

Case 3: Names sorted alphabetically

â†’ You keep halving the list
âš¡ Fast â†’ O(log n)

ğŸ“Š Common Big-O Classes (Must Memorize)

Big-O Name Real Meaning
O(1) Constant Always same time
O(log n) Logarithmic Divide & conquer
O(n) Linear Scan once
O(n log n) Log-linear Efficient sorting
O(nÂ²) Quadratic Nested loops
O(2â¿) Exponential Very slow

âš™ï¸ O(1) â€” Constant Time

Time does not depend on input size.

def get_first(arr):
    return arr[0]

No matter how big arr is â†’ still 1 step.

ğŸ“Œ Examples:

  • Array index access
  • Hash map lookup
  • Stack push/pop

ğŸ“ˆ O(n) â€” Linear Time

Runtime grows directly with input size.

def linear_search(arr, x):
    for v in arr:
        if v == x:
            return True
    return False

If input doubles â†’ time doubles.

ğŸ“Œ Examples:

  • Counting frequency
  • Finding max/min
  • Scanning data

âš¡ O(log n) â€” Logarithmic Time

Each step cuts the problem in half.

def binary_search(arr, x):
    l, r = 0, len(arr) - 1
    while l <= r:
        mid = (l + r) // 2
        if arr[mid] == x:
            return True
        elif arr[mid] < x:
            l = mid + 1
        else:
            r = mid - 1
    return False

Even for 1 million elements, only ~20 steps!

ğŸ“Œ Examples:

  • Binary search
  • Tree traversal (balanced)

ğŸ§  O(n log n) â€” Efficient Algorithms

Often comes from:

  • Divide problem
  • Solve subproblems
  • Combine results
sorted(nums)

Python uses Timsort â†’ O(n log n)

ğŸ“Œ Examples:

  • Merge sort
  • Quick sort (average case)
  • Heap sort

ğŸš¨ O(nÂ²) â€” Quadratic Time

Usually caused by nested loops.

for i in range(n):
    for j in range(n):
        do_something()

If n = 10,000 â†’ 100 million operations ğŸ˜±

ğŸ“Œ Examples:

  • Pair comparisons
  • Brute-force two sum
  • Duplicate detection (naive)
Nested loops usually mean?

O(nÂ²)

ğŸ”¥ Why O(nÂ²) Is Dangerous

n Operations
100 10,000
1,000 1,000,000
10,000 100,000,000

This is why LeetCode TLE (Time Limit Exceeded) happens.

ğŸ§ª Exam-Style Questions

Q1

for x in arr:
    print(x)

âœ… O(n)

Q2

for i in range(n):
    for j in range(i):
        print(i, j)

âœ… O(nÂ²)

Q3

i = 1
while i < n:
    i *= 2

âœ… O(log n)

ğŸ§  Space Complexity (Also Important)

Big-O also applies to memory usage.

seen = set()
for x in arr:
    seen.add(x)
  • Time: O(n)
  • Space: O(n)

Interviewers love this question:

â€œCan you trade space for time?â€

ğŸ¯ Real-World Engineering Insight

Situation Preferred
Small data Simple code
Large data Better Big-O
Real-time system Predictable complexity
AI pipelines Vectorized / O(n)

ğŸ Golden Interview Rule

First make it work. Then make it fast. Then explain why.

If you can explain Big-O clearly, you already sound like a professional.

ğŸ‰ Final Takeaway

Big-O is not math. Big-O is thinking about scale.

Once you see it everywhere:

  • LeetCode becomes easier
  • Code becomes cleaner
  • Interviews become calmer ğŸ˜„

Youâ€™re officially past beginner level ğŸš€

item.title: CS101-LC03 â€” Python for Interviews (From Zero to Thinking Like an Engineer)
item.description:
ğŸ¯ Why Python Matters in Interviews (Real World Edition)

Python is not tested because it is easy.

Python is tested because:

It exposes how you think.

Interviewers look for:

  • Can you break a problem into steps?
  • Do you choose the right container?
  • Can you read your own code after 6 months?
  • Do you understand cost (time & memory)?

Python is a mirror of your thinking quality.

ğŸ§  How Strong Python Engineers Think

Before writing code, they ask:

  1. What is the input shape?
  2. What must I track?
  3. What repeats? (loops)
  4. What must be fast lookup? (set / dict)
  5. What logic can become a function?

This chapter builds that instinct.

1. Absolute Basics (Interview Warm-Up)

These problems look deceptively easy, yet many candidates fail them â€” not because they canâ€™t code, but because they donâ€™t think flexibly.

ğŸ’¡ The goal is not to memorize one solution,
but to understand why many solutions are possible.

1.1 Problem â€” Count Prime Numbers

Task

Given an integer n, count how many prime numbers are strictly less than n.

A prime number is a number:

  • greater than 1
  • divisible only by 1 and itself

1.2 Baseline Reference Solution (Most Common)

This is the solution everyone knows â€” and thatâ€™s exactly why itâ€™s not enough.

def count_primes(n):
    def is_prime(x):
        if x < 2:
            return False
        for i in range(2, int(x**0.5) + 1):
            if x % i == 0:
                return False
        return True

    count = 0
    for i in range(n):
        if is_prime(i):
            count += 1
    return count

âœ… Correct âŒ Predictable âŒ Shows only one way of thinking

1.3 How Strong Candidates Think About is_prime(x)

A strong engineer does not ask:

â€œHow do I write is_prime?â€

They ask:

â€œWhat conditions must be violated for a number to be prime?â€

This mindset unlocks multiple valid implementations.

1.3.1 Idea 1 â€” Divisor Search (For Loop)

Thinking:

â€œIf a number has any divisor other than 1 and itself, itâ€™s not prime.â€

  • Stop early when a divisor is found
  • No need to check beyond âˆšx

This leads to the classic for-loop solution.

1.3.2 Idea 2 â€” Same Logic, Different Control Flow (while loop)

Thinking:

â€œThe logic doesnâ€™t depend on for â€” it depends on iteration.â€

def is_prime(x):
    if x < 2:
        return False
    i = 2
    while i * i <= x:
        if x % i == 0:
            return False
        i += 1
    return True

âœ¨ Same math âœ¨ Same correctness âœ¨ Different reasoning style

This shows control-flow mastery, not memorization.

1.3.3 Idea 3 â€” Mathematical Elimination

Thinking:

â€œMost numbers are not prime. Can I eliminate many cases early?â€

def is_prime(x):
    if x < 2:
        return False
    if x == 2:
        return True
    if x % 2 == 0:
        return False

    i = 3
    while i * i <= x:
        if x % i == 0:
            return False
        i += 2
    return True

ğŸ¯ Insight:

  • Skip even numbers entirely
  • Half the work, same correctness

This demonstrates performance awareness.

1.3.4 Idea 4 â€” Conceptual Shift (Precomputation)

Thinking:

â€œWhy test each number independently?â€

Instead:

  • Precompute primes once
  • Reuse results

This leads naturally to:

  • Sieve of Eratosthenes
  • Boolean arrays
  • Timeâ€“space tradeoffs

ğŸš€ This is how simple problems evolve into algorithms

1.4 What Interviewers Actually Evaluate

They are not checking if you remember sqrt(x).

They look for:

  • âœ” Logical decomposition
  • âœ” Early termination
  • âœ” Control-flow flexibility
  • âœ” Mathematical intuition
  • âœ” Ability to explain why a solution works

1.5 Teaching Message

If you can write the same logic in multiple ways, you truly understand it.

Anyone can copy:

for i in range(2, int(x**0.5) + 1):

Only strong thinkers can say:

â€œThatâ€™s just one way to express the idea.â€

2. Interview Follow-Up â€” Get All Prime Numbers

After you solve counting primes, a strong interviewer often asks:

â“ â€œOkay. How would you return all prime numbers?â€

This is where thinking depth matters.

2.1 First Question to Ask Yourself (Very Important)

A weak candidate immediately writes code.

A strong candidate pauses and asks:

ğŸ§  â€œUp to what range?â€
ğŸ§  â€œOnce or many queries?â€
ğŸ§  â€œDo I care about speed or memory?â€

These questions decide the solution.

2.2 Method 1 â€” Brute Force (Trial Division)

Idea

â€œA number is prime if it survives divisor testing.â€

This is the most direct extension of is_prime(x).

def all_primes_bruteforce(n):
    primes = []

    for x in range(2, n):
        is_prime = True
        for i in range(2, int(x**0.5) + 1):
            if x % i == 0:
                is_prime = False
                break
        if is_prime:
            primes.append(x)

    return primes

Why This Still Matters

âœ” Easy to explain âœ” Easy to verify âœ” Good for small n âŒ Repeats work many times

Interview signal: â€œI understand the baseline before optimizing.â€

2.3 Method 2 â€” Control-Flow Mastery (While-Based Thinking)

Idea

â€œThe algorithm doesnâ€™t depend on for â€” only on logic.â€

def all_primes_while(n):
    primes = []

    x = 2
    while x < n:
        i = 2
        prime = True
        while i * i <= x:
            if x % i == 0:
                prime = False
                break
            i += 1
        if prime:
            primes.append(x)
        x += 1

    return primes

Why Interviewers Like This

âœ” Shows loop control confidence âœ” Demonstrates flexibility âœ” Not locked to syntax patterns

Same math, different brain.

2.4 Method 3 â€” Mathematical Elimination (Smarter Trial Division)

Idea

â€œMost numbers are obviously not prime.â€

Key observations:

  • 2 is the only even prime
  • Skip all even numbers
  • Check only odd divisors
def all_primes_optimized(n):
    if n <= 2:
        return []

    primes = [2]

    for x in range(3, n, 2):
        prime = True
        for i in range(3, int(x**0.5) + 1, 2):
            if x % i == 0:
                prime = False
                break
        if prime:
            primes.append(x)

    return primes

Interview Gold Signal

âœ” Cuts work ~50% âœ” Shows mathematical reasoning âœ” Same correctness, better performance

2.5 Method 4 â€” Conceptual Leap (Sieve of Eratosthenes)

Idea Shift (This Is the Key Moment)

Instead of asking:

â€œIs this number prime?â€

Ask:

â€œWhich numbers are definitely NOT prime?â€

This flips the problem.

Sieve Algorithm

def all_primes_sieve(n):
    if n <= 2:
        return []

    is_prime = [True] * n
    is_prime[0] = is_prime[1] = False

    p = 2
    while p * p < n:
        if is_prime[p]:
            for multiple in range(p * p, n, p):
                is_prime[multiple] = False
        p += 1

    return [i for i in range(n) if is_prime[i]]

Why This Impresses Interviewers

âœ” Classic algorithm knowledge âœ” Time complexity: O(n log log n) âœ” No repeated primality checks âœ” Shows algorithmic maturity

This is where warm-up ends and real CS begins.

2.6 Method 5 â€” Incremental Prime Building (Reuse Knowledge)

Idea

â€œTo test a number, I only need previous primes.â€

def all_primes_incremental(n):
    primes = []

    for x in range(2, n):
        prime = True
        for p in primes:
            if p * p > x:
                break
            if x % p == 0:
                prime = False
                break
        if prime:
            primes.append(x)

    return primes

Why This Is Subtle and Powerful

âœ” Avoids redundant checks âœ” Natural optimization âœ” Bridges brute force â†’ sieve thinking

Interviewers often smile at this one ğŸ˜„

2.7 How to Explain This Like a Pro (Talking Points)

When asked â€œHow do you get all primes?â€, say:

â€œThere are multiple valid strategies, depending on constraints.â€

Then briefly summarize:

Method Key Idea Best When
Brute force Test each number Small n, clarity
Optimized trial Skip evens Medium n
Incremental Reuse primes Streaming primes
Sieve Mark composites Large n

2.8 Teaching Message (Very Strong)

The problem is not about primes. It is about how you think, structure, and optimize.

If a student can:

  • Write it in multiple ways
  • Explain why each works
  • Choose based on constraints

ğŸ‘‰ They are interview-ready.

3. Containers & Indexing â€” The Hidden Power Behind Easy Problems

Many interview problems are labeled easy.

They are not testing difficulty.
They are testing how well you control containers and indexing.

3.1 Containers You Must Master (Not Memorize)

Before writing any algorithm, ask:

ğŸ§  â€œWhat container represents my idea most clearly?â€

Container When to Use Interview Signal
list Ordered, indexed data Iteration, slicing
set Uniqueness, fast lookup Optimization thinking
dict Mapping, frequency Real-world modeling
tuple Fixed structure Safety & intent

Most LeetCode problems are container problems in disguise.

3.2 Indexing â€” Where Real Control Begins

Basic Indexing

arr = [10, 20, 30, 40, 50]

arr[0]    # 10
arr[1]    # 20
arr[-1]   # 50
arr[-2]   # 40

ğŸ§  Thinking:

  • Positive index â†’ from the front
  • Negative index â†’ from the back

Interview hint: Negative indexing often removes edge-case code.

3.3 Slicing Syntax (Start : Stop : Step)

This is non-negotiable knowledge.

arr[start : stop : step]
Component Meaning
start Where to begin (inclusive)
stop Where to end (exclusive)
step How to move

3.3.1 Basic Slicing (Warm-Up)

arr = [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

arr[1:5]     # [1, 2, 3, 4]
arr[:4]      # [0, 1, 2, 3]
arr[3:]      # [3, 4, 5, 6]
arr[:]       # full copy

ğŸ§  Thinking:

â€œPython slicing avoids off-by-one bugs.â€

3.4 Step â€” Where You Impress People

Skipping Elements

arr[::2]     # every 2nd element
arr[1::2]    # odd indices

Used in:

  • Optimizing prime checks
  • Sampling data
  • Window-based problems

Reverse Without a Loop (ğŸ”¥ Interview Favorite)

arr[::-1]

No temp variables No loop No bugs

Many candidates forget this. Interviewers do not.

3.5 Advanced Slicing Patterns (Real LeetCode Use)

Process Only Odd Numbers

nums = list(range(20))
odds = nums[1::2]

Used in:

  • Prime optimization
  • Parity problems
  • Bit manipulation prep

Sliding Window Intuition (Without Writing It Yet)

window_size = 3
for i in range(len(arr) - window_size + 1):
    window = arr[i : i + window_size]

ğŸ§  This idea powers:

  • Max subarray
  • Moving average
  • Time-series features
  • NLP n-grams

3.6 range(start, stop, step) â€” The Loop Twin of Slicing

Many people misuse range.

Strong candidates design it.

range(start, stop, step)

Examples That Matter

range(5)           # 0,1,2,3,4
range(2, 10)       # 2..9
range(1, 10, 2)    # odd numbers
range(10, 0, -1)   # reverse loop

Prime Optimization Example (Tie Back)

for i in range(3, int(x**0.5) + 1, 2):
    ...

ğŸ§  Insight:

  • Start at 3
  • Stop at âˆšx
  • Step by 2 (skip evens)

This is not syntax â€” it is thinking encoded into iteration.

3.7 Containers + Indexing = Real-World Thinking

Example: Marking Non-Primes (Sieve Recall)

is_prime = [True] * n
is_prime[0] = is_prime[1] = False
  • Container choice: list
  • Index = number itself
  • Value = property of that number

This is how abstract math becomes code.

3.8 Interviewer Mental Checklist (They Wonâ€™t Tell You)

They silently ask:

  • Does this candidate know slicing?
  • Do they avoid unnecessary loops?
  • Can they control iteration boundaries?
  • Can they reverse, skip, and window cleanly?
  • Do they understand start/stop/step?

If yes â†’ strong hire signal

3.9 Teaching Message (Very Strong)

Containers are not data. They are thinking tools.

If you master:

  • Indexing
  • Slicing
  • Step control

Then:

  • Your code is shorter
  • Your logic is clearer
  • Your interviews go smoother

3.10 Final Impression Line (Use This Verbally)

â€œMost problems are solved not by clever algorithms, but by precise control of containers and iteration.â€

ğŸ”¥ This framing always impresses.

4. Applied Problem â€” Lionel Messi at FC Barcelona ğŸ

Abstract concepts only stick when people can see them in real life.

So letâ€™s apply containers and indexing to a story everyone knows.

4.1 Problem Story (Real-World Framing)

Lionel Messi played for FC Barcelona from 2004 to 2021.

Each season, we record how many goals he scored in all competitions.

messi_goals = [
    1,   # 2004
    6,   # 2005
    17,  # 2006
    16,  # 2007
    38,  # 2008
    47,  # 2009
    53,  # 2010
    73,  # 2011 (peak)
    60,  # 2012
    41,  # 2013
    58,  # 2014
    41,  # 2015
    54,  # 2016
    45,  # 2017
    51,  # 2018
    36,  # 2019
    31   # 2020
]

ğŸ§  Container choice:

  • list â†’ ordered by time
  • index â†’ season offset
  • value â†’ performance

This is already data modeling.

4.2 Problem 1 â€” First, Last, and Peak Seasons

Task

  • First season goals
  • Last season goals
  • Peak scoring season

Solution (Indexing)

first_season = messi_goals[0]
last_season = messi_goals[-1]
peak_goals = max(messi_goals)

ğŸ§  Thinking:

  • Index 0 â†’ beginning of career
  • Index -1 â†’ end of career
  • Built-in functions reduce logic noise

4.3 Problem 2 â€” Prime Messi Era (Slicing)

Story

Fans often say:

â€œMessiâ€™s prime years were from 2009 to 2012.â€

Task

Extract only those seasons.

Thinking First

  • Data starts at 2004
  • 2009 is index 5
  • 2012 is index 8 (exclusive â†’ stop at 9)

Solution

prime_years = messi_goals[5:9]

Result:

[47, 53, 73, 60]

ğŸ§  This is timeline slicing â€” used everywhere in real systems.

4.4 Problem 3 â€” Every Other Season (Step Control)

Story

Analysts want to study long-term consistency, skipping every other season.

Task

Select goals from alternating seasons.

Solution

alternate_seasons = messi_goals[::2]

ğŸ§  Meaning:

  • Start at beginning
  • Go to end
  • Step = 2

This pattern appears in:

  • Sampling
  • Signal processing
  • Optimization loops

4.5 Problem 4 â€” Late-Career Decline Analysis (Negative Indexing)

Story

Sports analysts often study late-career performance.

Task

Extract the last 5 seasons.

Solution

late_career = messi_goals[-5:]

ğŸ§  Why this is powerful:

  • No need to know list length
  • Works even if data grows
  • Avoids edge-case bugs

4.6 Problem 5 â€” Reverse Career Timeline (Interview Favorite)

Story

A visualization tool wants data from last season to first.

Task

Reverse the list.

Solution

reverse_timeline = messi_goals[::-1]

ğŸ”¥ No loop ğŸ”¥ No temp variable ğŸ”¥ Clean and expressive

Interviewers love this.

4.7 Problem 6 â€” Sliding Window (Form Analysis)

Story

Coaches analyze 3-season form windows.

Task

Compute 3-season goal windows.

Solution

window_size = 3
windows = []

for i in range(len(messi_goals) - window_size + 1):
    window = messi_goals[i : i + window_size]
    windows.append(window)

ğŸ§  This exact pattern appears in:

  • Stock prices
  • Time-series forecasting
  • NLP n-grams
  • Sports analytics

4.8 Problem 7 â€” Labeling Seasons with a Dictionary

Story

We want to map season â†’ goals.

Solution (Container Upgrade)

years = list(range(2004, 2004 + len(messi_goals)))
messi_by_year = dict(zip(years, messi_goals))

Now you can ask:

messi_by_year[2011]   # 73

ğŸ§  This is real-world data modeling, not toy code.

4.9 Interviewer-Level Insight (Say This Out Loud)

â€œI model time-series data using ordered containers, then use indexing and slicing to express questions clearly.â€

This sentence alone changes how interviewers see you.

4.10 Teaching Message (Strong & Memorable)

Containers tell the story. Indexing lets you ask questions. Slicing answers them cleanly.

If students understand this section, they are:

  • LeetCode-ready
  • Interview-ready
  • Real-world-ready

5. Olympic Puzzle â€” The Messi Challenge (Advanced Edition) ğŸ…âš½

This puzzle looks fun.

In reality, it tests:

  • loop control
  • state tracking
  • early exits
  • skipping logic
  • recursion thinking

Exactly what top interviews look for.

5.1 The Dataset (Given)

messi_goals = [
    1, 6, 17, 16, 38, 47, 53, 73, 60,
    41, 58, 41, 54, 45, 51, 36, 31
]

Each element is goals per season, in order.

5.2 Olympic Rules (Strict)

You must use:

âœ… for loop âœ… while loop âœ… break âœ… continue âœ… indexing or slicing âœ… at least one container â­ recursion = bonus gold medal

âŒ No max() âŒ No sorting âŒ No libraries

5.3 The Challenge ğŸ§©

Main Task

Find the longest consecutive streak where:

Messi scored more than 40 goals in back-to-back seasons

Then output:

  1. Length of the streak
  2. Goals in the streak

5.4 Think Like an Engineer (Say This First)

â€œThis is sequential data, so I will scan it linearly and track state transitions.â€

That sentence alone is interview gold.

5.5 Core Scan â€” while Loop + continue

i = 0
current = []
longest = []

This problem looks simple, but interviewers often use it to evaluate:

[1] [1]

ğŸ§  Interviewer Insight (Read This First)

â— Important:
In real interviews, the question is not â€œCan you sort an array?â€
It is:

  • Which sorting algorithm do you choose?
  • Why is it optimal for this scenario?
  • What are the time & space trade-offs?

Below we show all major sorting algorithms with clear intuition.

âœ… Approach 1 â€” Python Built-in Sort (Recommended in Practice)

ğŸ’¡ Idea

Python uses Timsort, a hybrid of:

  • Merge Sort
  • Insertion Sort

It is:

  • Stable
  • Extremely fast in real-world data
  • Optimized for partially sorted arrays

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def sort_array(nums):

ğŸŸ¢ Use this in interviews unless explicitly forbidden.

ğŸ§© Approach 2 â€” Bubble Sort (Educational Only)

ğŸ’¡ Idea

Repeatedly swap adjacent elements if they are in the wrong order.

Think of large numbers â€œbubbling upâ€ to the end.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def bubble_sort(nums):
    n = len(nums)
    for i in range(n):
        for j in range(0, n - i - 1):
            if nums[j] > nums[j + 1]:
                nums[j], nums[j + 1] = nums[j + 1], nums[j]
    return nums

â±ï¸ Complexity

  • Time: O(nÂ²)
  • Space: O(1)

ğŸ”´ Rarely used in practice, but good for teaching basics.

ğŸ§© Approach 3 â€” Selection Sort

ğŸ’¡ Idea

Repeatedly find the minimum element and move it to the front.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def selection_sort(nums):
    n = len(nums)
    for i in range(n):
        min_idx = i
        for j in range(i + 1, n):
            if nums[j] < nums[min_idx]:
                min_idx = j
        nums[i], nums[min_idx] = nums[min_idx], nums[i]
    return nums

â±ï¸ Complexity

  • Time: O(nÂ²)
  • Space: O(1)

ğŸŸ¡ Simple but inefficient for large data.

ğŸ§© Approach 4 â€” Insertion Sort

ğŸ’¡ Idea

Build the sorted array one element at a time, similar to sorting playing cards.

Very efficient for nearly sorted arrays.

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def insertion_sort(nums):
    for i in range(1, len(nums)):
        key = nums[i]
        j = i - 1
        while j >= 0 and nums[j] > key:
            nums[j + 1] = nums[j]
            j -= 1
        nums[j + 1] = key
    return nums

â±ï¸ Complexity

  • Time: O(nÂ²) worst case, O(n) best case
  • Space: O(1)

ğŸŸ¢ Excellent when data is almost sorted.

ğŸ§© Approach 5 â€” Merge Sort (Divide & Conquer)

ğŸ’¡ Idea

  • Divide the array into halves
  • Sort each half
  • Merge them back together

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def merge_sort(nums):
    if len(nums) <= 1:
        return nums

    mid = len(nums) // 2
    left = merge_sort(nums[:mid])
    right = merge_sort(nums[mid:])

    return merge(left, right)

def merge(left, right):
    result = []
    i = j = 0

    while i < len(left) and j < len(right):
        if left[i] < right[j]:
            result.append(left[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            result.append(right[j])
            j += 1

    result.extend(left[i:])
    result.extend(right[j:])
    return result

â±ï¸ Complexity

  • Time: O(n log n)
  • Space: O(n)

ğŸŸ¢ Very popular in interviews.

ğŸ§© Approach 6 â€” Quick Sort (Average Fastest)

ğŸ’¡ Idea

  • Pick a pivot
  • Partition elements into smaller & larger
  • Recursively sort

ğŸ§‘â€ğŸ’» Code

def quick_sort(nums):
    if len(nums) <= 1:
        return nums

    pivot = nums[len(nums) // 2]
    left = [x for x in nums if x < pivot]
    middle = [x for x in nums if x == pivot]
    right = [x for x in nums if x > pivot]

    return quick_sort(left) + middle + quick_sort(right)

â±ï¸ Complexity

  • Time: O(n log n) average, O(nÂ²) worst
  • Space: O(n)

ğŸŸ¢ Very fast in practice, but discuss worst case.

Nearly sorted data Insertion Sort
Guaranteed performance Merge Sort
Average fastest Quick Sort

ğŸ§  Takeaway

Sorting is not about memorizing code. Itâ€™s about choosing the right tool for the problem.

from collections import Counter

def minWindow(s, t):
    need = Counter(t)
    missing = len(t)
    left = start = end = 0

    for right, ch in enumerate(s, 1):
        if need[ch] > 0:
            missing -= 1
        need[ch] -= 1

        if missing == 0:
            while left < right and need[s[left]] < 0:
                need[s[left]] += 1
                left += 1

            if end == 0 or right - left < end - start:
                start, end = left, right

            need[s[left]] += 1
            missing += 1
            left += 1

    return s[start:end]

  • Time: O(n)
  • Space: O(k) (character set)

    # ---------- Parse Matches ----------
    def parse_matches(data):
        matches = []
        for rec in data.split(","):
            stage, ta, ga, tb, gb = rec.split("|")
            matches.append({
                "stage": stage,
                "A": ta,
                "B": tb,
                "ga": int(ga),
                "gb": int(gb)
            })
        return matches

    matches = parse_matches(data)

    # ---------- 1ï¸âƒ£ Group Standings ----------
    standings = {}

    def update(team, goals_for, goals_against):
        if team not in standings:
            standings[team] = {"points": 0, "gd": 0}
        standings[team]["gd"] += goals_for - goals_against

        if goals_for > goals_against:
            standings[team]["points"] += 3
        elif goals_for == goals_against:
            standings[team]["points"] += 1

    for m in matches:
        if m["stage"] == "GROUP":
            update(m["A"], m["ga"], m["gb"])
            update(m["B"], m["gb"], m["ga"])

    # ---------- 2ï¸âƒ£ Top Attacking Teams ----------

        for s in stages:

        max_run = curr = 0

                curr += 1
                max_run = max(max_run, curr)
            else:
                curr = 0

        survival[team] = max_run

    # ---------- 4ï¸âƒ£ Most Dramatic Window ----------
    max_goals = 0
    best_window = []

    for i in range(len(matches) - 2):
        window = matches[i:i+3]
        total = sum(m["ga"] + m["gb"] for m in window)

    # ---------- 5ï¸âƒ£ Champion Summary ----------

    champ = final["A"] if final["ga"] > final["gb"] else final["B"]

            conceded += m["gb"]

            conceded += m["ga"]

    summary = (

    )

            "matches": best_window,
            "total_goals": max_goals

    }

ğŸ“˜ What Is TF-IDF? (Intuition + Math)

TF-IDF stands for:

Term Frequency â€“ Inverse Document Frequency

It answers one fundamental NLP question:

â Which words are important in this document,
compared to the entire collection? â

ğŸ§® The Math (Step by Step)

1ï¸âƒ£ Term Frequency (TF)

How often a word appears inside one document.

$$ \text{TF}(w, d) = \frac{\text{count of } w \text{ in document } d} {\text{total words in document } d} $$

ğŸ‘‰ Measures local importance

2ï¸âƒ£ Document Frequency (DF)

How many documents contain the word.

$$ \text{DF}(w) = \text{number of documents containing } w $$

ğŸ‘‰ Measures how common a word is across documents

3ï¸âƒ£ Inverse Document Frequency (IDF)

Penalizes words appearing in many documents.

$$ \text{IDF}(w) = \log\left(\frac{N}{\text{DF}(w)}\right) $$

Where:

  • $N$ = total number of documents

ğŸ‘‰ Measures global rarity

4ï¸âƒ£ TF-IDF (Final Score)

$$ \text{TF-IDF}(w, d) = \text{TF}(w, d) \times \text{IDF}(w) $$

This is the importance score used in:

  • search engines
  • document ranking
  • classical NLP systems

ğŸ§ª Worked Example (Very Important)

Corpus (3 documents)

D1: "messi scores goals"
D2: "goals win matches"
D3: "messi inspires fans"

Step 1: Vocabulary

{messi, scores, goals, win, matches, inspires, fans}

Step 2: Document Frequency (DF)

Word DF
messi 2
goals 2
scores 1
win 1
matches 1
inspires 1
fans 1

Step 3: IDF (Assume natural log)

$$ \text{IDF}(\text{messi}) = \log\left(\frac{3}{2}\right) $$

$$ \text{IDF}(\text{scores}) = \log\left(\frac{3}{1}\right) $$

ğŸ‘‰ "scores" appears in fewer documents ğŸ‘‰ therefore it has higher IDF

Step 4: TF-IDF in Document 1

Document 1 contains 3 words:

messi scores goals
Word TF IDF TF-IDF
messi 1/3 log(3/2) low
scores 1/3 log(3/1) HIGH
goals 1/3 log(3/2) low

âœ… “scores” becomes the most important word

ğŸ¯ What Interviewers Want You To Say

If asked:

â€œExplain TF-IDFâ€

A perfect answer is:

â€œTF-IDF measures how important a word is to a document relative to the whole corpus.

It boosts words that are frequent in one document but rare across documents.â€

ğŸ”— Why TF-IDF Still Matters Today

Even in the age of GPT:

  • Search engines still use it
  • Keyword extraction uses it
  • It explains why attention exists
  • It is the conceptual ancestor of embeddings

If you understand TF-IDF deeply, transformers feel natural â€” not magical.

â€œWhich words matter?â€

  • semantic meaning

âš½ Messi & Meaning â€” A Short Story

Common words are like defenders:

  • they are everywhere
  • they mean little

Rare words are like Messi:

  • fewer appearances
  • massive impact

That is TF-IDF.

ğŸ”´ TF-IDF 15 â€” Big Data MapReduce TF

ğŸ”´ TF-IDF 16 â€” Rare Word Detection

ğŸ”´ TF-IDF 17 â€” Explainability Test

ğŸ¯ Final Message
